Neither does it help when women still find it embarrassing to report a sexual assault, that women are almost always asked during the process of making such reports whether they were sober and were modestly dressed during the incident, and when women are advised to, forced and even legally allowed under certain laws to marry their rapists to uphold “honour” 
Worse, when some who dared to call themselves ustaz advocated for women to not dress “sexily when going to bed alone, to avoid being raped by djinns”. These ustaz are missing the point – 
Victim-blaming and inciting fear among women to the point of affecting our ability to live our lives have not and will not solve the issue of such crimes. In our need to uphold the law, advocate human rights and enshrine the need for private citizen’ 
Most chilling was a now-deleted tweet from a Malay youth, echoed by many men, whereby he sanctioned rape as a punishment for women who are “stubborn about covering up and enjoy going out of the house” (“Biar selva kumar kasi ajar la sikit anak dara yang degil tk tutup aurat dan suka keluar rumah” 
This type of mentality – that women are less than men, objectified and sexualised beyond extent – is the crux of the problem. Whether putting the blame on djinns for one’ 
The way forward should begin by shifting the blame to the perpetrators of such crimes. Rapists should serve their meted sentences, regardless of their “bright future” 
The public’s current anger should be best used to pressure our Members of Parliament to push for a sexual offender’ 
There should be open communication between parents and children. Our youths should also no longer learn about sex from pornographic materials, but through “sex talk”h their parents and sex-positive educational materials online (such as the Popek channel on YouTube), books, and our school counsellors should be empowered with a comprehensive sex education syllabus. 
“Teach men not to rape” is neither parody nor feminist clich; it is what is needed to address this issue.
